Text.Value: As am I.
I may have lost Wulbren. But I don't leave this place friendless. That much I know for certain.
I wish it hadn't ended like this, but I know you did all you could to help Wulbren - to help me.
What about you? I doubt he's happy with you either.
Go on, now - I know the way home from here.
And now I have a great responsibility to boot. I'm not sure I know how to lead the Ironhand Gnomes, but I won't do worse than Wulbren, that's for sure.
Wulbren deserved to die.
So many dead. Gondians. Ironhands... Wulbren. This wasn't supposed to happen.

EditorData.logicalname: Lost both sides (Gondians and wulbren dead)

Text.Value: Like the Gondians who burn in the foundry as we speak?
I just saw you murder innocent people - you think I don't know what you're capable of?
So it seems. I don't know when he became so... angry. Perhaps he always was, and I was too naive to see it.
No. No, I don't think you did.
Well. Here we are. A most unexpected outcome.

EditorData.NodeContext: barcus has become leader of the ironhand gnomes

Text.Value: Let him come - I'll be ready.
We won't meet again. Good day.
Someone like that cannot lead the Ironhand Gnomes. We need peace.
I must... inform his family. Arrange his affairs, as much as I'm able.
I'm sorry it ended like this.
You - this was not the deal! You were meant to stop this madness - not... not... enmadden it!

EditorData.NodeContext: furious with player who has caused a LOT of deaths

Text.Value: I did what I could.
This was for the best - now nobody gets Baldur's Gate.
I may have lost Wulbren. But I found a far preferable ally. Friend, even.
Wulbren might be a violent bastard, but I have the privilege of being better than him.
Why can't he let the Gondians be?
Go on - you have a city to save or something, don't you?
I'm sorry - there was no other way.
I wish you had left me tied to that infernal windmill. At least I would have been spared witnessing this horror.
I'm starting to see the truth of him, believe it or not. My expectations of that mugungus have changed significantly. But I still want the best for him.
Still, I just can't save Wulbren. He won't rest until the Gondians are dead. And you in the bargain.

EditorData.NodeContext: sad - he knows his friend is gone

Text.Value: Shoo, then. For now. My friend.

EditorData.NodeContext: Barcus' awkward goodbye. Pathos underneath it, his stiffness in the middle. Affectionate but awkward.

Text.Value: You'll make a great leader of the Ironhand Gnomes.
I wish you the very best. And then a little on top.
I know. And one of you will die. Wulbren, I'd wager.
I'd tell you to write, but I never check the post. Farewell, my friend. And good luck.
Not the lives of the Gondians you left to die? The bodies that burn in the foundry as we speak?
Which is why I'm going after him. Someone has to stop him from ending his life in a blaze of foolishness.
The Steel Watch is gone - that's all that matters.
Perhaps. But while you saw a madman, I saw the boy he once was.
Thank you for your encouragement. I needed it. And have done since the day we met.
Lies, lies, and more lies. You chose this horror show. You should have left me tied to that infernal windmill. At least then I would've died without these horrible images in my mind.
'Stopped'? Such a toothless word for cold-blooded murder.
I don't know when he became so angry - so violent. But I'm glad to say I see the truth of it now. At last.
The Gondians were a threat - they had to be stopped.
You stood up to Wulbren - I'm impressed.
I take no pleasure in ousting Wulbren. But he's not the old friend I remember. When did he get so angry? So violent?
Because he has the same weakness as the Gondians - pride. He's simply more honest about it. And more brutal.
I followed him through the city, to the wilds, through the Underdark, and back home again. Braved goblins, shades, and evils I could hardly describe.
Wulbren was past saving.
I am many things - a leader is not one of them. But no time like the present to learn. And I can't do worse than Wulbren, sorry as I am to say it.
Still, I couldn't save Wulbren from himself. I don't think anyone could.
I have nothing left to say to you.
Now! Myself and the Ironhand Gnomes have much to disentangle. But when you're ready to face what's waiting for you, believe me: we will be at your side.

EditorData.NodeContext: Too much vulnerability! Back to brass tacks.

Text.Value: You want to die too, Barcus?
These were people. Friends. Families.
You should have killed Wulbren.
Let's be honest. Wulbren hasn't been happy with me in... hm. Ever, upon reflection.

Synopsis: A completely optional dialog with Barcus after the outcome of the Steel Watch Foundry has concluded. After the other gnomes leave Barcus sticks around until the next long rest. He looks at the burning Foundry and will react to what decisions you have made.
